{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox cricketer | name = John Trask | country = England | fullname = John Ernest Trask | birth_date = {{Birth date|1861|10|27|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Brympton]], [[Somerset]], [[England]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1896|07|25|1861|10|27|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Kosheh, Sudan]], [[Sudan]] | batting = Right-handed | bowling = Right-arm [[Medium pace bowling|medium]] | role = Batsman | club1 = [[Somerset County Cricket Club|Somerset]] | year1 = 1884–1895 | club2 = [[Europeans cricket team|Europeans]] | year2 = 1892–1895 | club3 = [[Mumbai cricket team|Bombay]] | year3 = 1892–93 | type1 = First-class | debutdate1 = 18 August | debutyear1 = 1884 | debutfor1 = [[Somerset County Cricket Club|Somerset]] | debutagainst1 = [[Hampshire County Cricket Club|Hampshire]] | lastdate1 = 29 July | lastyear1 = 1895 | lastfor1 = [[Somerset County Cricket Club|Somerset]] | lastagainst1 = [[Kent County Cricket Club|Kent]] | columns = 1 | column1 = [[First-class cricket|First-class]] | matches1 = 16 | runs1 = 515 | bat avg1 = 19.07 | 100s/50s1 = 0/3 | top score1 = 78 | deliveries1 = 10 | wickets1 = 0 | bowl avg1 = – | fivefor1 = 0 | tenfor1 = 0 | best bowling1 = 0/9 | catches/stumpings1 = 9/– | date = 6 January | year = 2010 | source = http://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/3/3857/3857.html CricketArchive }} [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|Surgeon-Captain]] '''John Ernest Trask''' (27 October 1861 – 25 July 1896) was an English [[cricket]]er who made 16 [[First-class cricket|first-class]] appearances. He played nine times for [[Somerset County Cricket Club|Somerset]] between 1884–1895, and also appeared in first-class matches in India. He served in the [[Royal Army Medical Corps|Army Medical Services]] from 1887 until his death from [[cholera]] in [[Sudan]] during 1896.
==Cricket career== Trask played three matches for Somerset in 1884 and 1885, making 44 runs in his five innings, but didn't return for the county until their successful 1890 season, when they won the 'Second-class Championship'. After helping Somerset regain their first-class status, he travelled to India with the Army, where he remained for four and a half years. During his time in the country, he made six first-class appearances for the [[Europeans cricket team]], and also played for [[Mumbai cricket team|Bombay]]. It was during this time that he made his highest score in first-class cricket, making 78 [[Batting order (cricket)|opening]] against [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/4/4055.html |title=Europeans v Parsees |publisher=[[CricketArchive]] |date=1893-09-19 |accessdate=2010-01-06}}</ref> He played six more matches for Somerset on his return home in 1895, but left again after a couple of months.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/3/3857/3857.html | title = John Trask |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate=2010-01-06}}</ref>
==Army career== After being educated in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], Trask attended the [[Bristol Medical School]], and entered the Army Medical Department in 1887,<ref name=BMJ /> after a short probationary period he was commissioned on 27 July 1887.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=25734|startpage=4697|date=30 August 1887|accessdate=6 January 2010}}</ref> After two years at [[Aldershot]], he was posted to [[India]] for almost five years. After a couple of months back in England during 1895,<ref name=BMJ /> he was seconded to the [[Egyptian Army]] on 23 August 1895.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=26658|startpage=4971|date=3 September 1895|accessdate=6 January 2010}}</ref> During this posting, he died of [[cholera]] during the Dongola Expedition on 25 July 1896.<ref name=BMJ>{{cite journal |date=1 August 1896 |title=Obituary: John Ernest Trask |journal=[[British Medical Journal]] |volume=2 |issue=1857 |page=305 |pmc=2510162 |accessdate=2010-01-06 |doi=10.1136/bmj.2.1857.305-a}}</ref> He was [[Mentioned in Despatches]] by [[Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener|Sir Herbert Kitchener]] (later Earl Kitchener) in a despatch dated 30 September 1896.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=26791|startpage=6001|endpage=6006|date=3 September 1895|accessdate=6 January 2010}}</ref> In an official notice relating to his [[estate (law)|estate]] published in the ''[[London Gazette]]'', his address is given as 40 St James Square, [[Holland Park]].<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=26836|startpage=1776|date=26 March 1897|accessdate=6 January 2010}}</ref>
==Arthur Conan Doyle's ''The New Revelation''== {{Quote box | quote =In answer to my questions it claimed to be the spirit of one whom I will call Dodd, who was a famous cricketer, and with whom I had some serious conversation in Cairo before he went up the Nile, where he met his death in the Dongolese Expedition. We have now, I may remark, come to the year 1896 in my experiences.<ref name="tnr">{{cite book |title=The New Revelation |last=Conan Doyle |first=Arthur |authorlink=Arthur Conan Doyle |year=2007 |publisher=Cosimo |origyear= 1918 |location=New York |isbn=978-1-60206-365-5 |page=19 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ui6_eW4zYdEC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_navlinks_s#v=onepage&q=&f=false |accessdate=2010-01-06}}</ref> | source = â€“ Arthur Conan Doyle – ''The New Revelation'' | width =30% | align =left }} In Sir [[Arthur Conan Doyle]]'s 1918 work ''The New Revelation'', Doyle gives his own views and thoughts on the relationship between spiritual revelations and conventional religious dogma. Within ''The New Revelation'', he makes reference to a conversation held with a [[spirit]] he chooses to call (for the purposes of the book) Dodd. [[Andrew Lycett]], author of ''The Man Who Created Sherlock Holmes; The Life and Times of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle'', claims that this spirit is in fact that of John Trask.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Man Who Created Sherlock Holmes; The Life and Times of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle |last=Lycett |first=Andrew|authorlink=Andrew Lycett |year=2007 |publisher=Weidenfield & Nicolson |location=London |isbn=1-4165-4580-8 |page=480}}</ref> Dodd is described as a famous cricketer that Doyle spoke to in Cairo, who had since died as part of the Dongolese Expedition. He then remarks that the event occurred in 1896.<ref name="tnr"/> These statements all support the assertion that the spirit is Trask, as his posting to the Egyptian Army would likely have seen him in Cairo, while his death is well documented as occurring during the Dongolese Expedition of 1896. His cricketing exploits in England and India may well have also been known to Doyle, who himself played ten first-class matches for the [[Marylebone Cricket Club|MCC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/11/11019/11019.html |title=Player Profile: Arthur Conan Doyle |publisher=[[CricketArchive]] |accessdate=2010-01-06}}</ref>
